public class TestConverterSet extends TestCase {
    // ...

    public void testRemoveConverterNotFound() {
        Converter[] array = new Converter[] {
            c1, c2, c3, c4,
        };
        ConverterSet set = new ConverterSet(array);
        Converter[] removed = new Converter[1];
        set.remove(new Converter() {
            public Class getSupportedType() {return Integer.class;}
        }, removed);
        assertSame(set, removed[0]);
        assertEquals(4, set.size());
    }

    public void testRemoveConverterFound() {
        Converter[] array = new Converter[] {
            c1, c2, c3, c4,
        };
        ConverterSet set = new ConverterSet(array);
        Converter[] removed = new Converter[1];
        set.remove(c4, removed);
        assertSame(c4, removed[0]);
        assertEquals(3, set.size());
    }
}
```
In these tests, `testRemoveConverterNotFound()` verifies that when the `remove` method is called with a Converter that does not exist in the ConverterSet, the ConverterSet is returned unchanged (`set.remove(new Converter() {public Class getSupportedType() {return Integer.class;}}, removed)`). And `testRemoveConverterFound()` verifies that when the `remove` method is called with an existing Converter, the Converter is removed from the ConverterSet (`set.remove(c4, removed)`).

public class TestDateTimeFormatter extends TestCase  {
    public void testParseInto() {
        // assuming that requireParser and selectChronology methods are already tested
        DateTimeFormatter formatter = new DateTimeFormatter(null, null);
        ReadWritableInstant instant = new ReadWritableInstant(1000);
        String text = "2004-06-09T10:20:30Z";
        int position = 0;
        
        int newPos = formatter.parseInto(instant, text, position);
        assertEquals(20, newPos); // the return value depends on the parser
        
        // test with null instant
        try {
            formatter.parseInto(null, text, position);
            fail("Expected IllegalArgumentException");
        } catch (IllegalArgumentException ex) {}
        
        // test with empty text
        newPos = formatter.parseInto(instant, "", position);
        assertEquals(0, newPos);
        
        // test with non-empty text but position greater than the text length
        newPos = formatter.parseInto(instant, text, text.length() + 1);
        assertEquals(-1, newPos); 
    }
}
```

Note: The test cases assume that the `requireParser` and `selectChronology` methods are already tested in your test class. Adjust the test cases if they are not.

public class TestBaseSingleFieldPeriod extends TestCase {
    private static final DateTimeZone PARIS = DateTimeZone.forID("Europe/Paris");

    public void testBetweenReadablePartial() throws Exception {
        // Test with normal objects
        long startMillis = PARIS.convertLocalToUTC(123456789000L);
        long endMillis = PARIS.convertLocalToUTC(startMillis + 1000000);
        ReadablePartial start = new Period().withMillis(startMillis);
        ReadablePartial end = new Period().withMillis(endMillis);
        ReadablePeriod zeroInstance = new Period();

        int result = BaseSingleFieldPeriod.between(start, end, zeroInstance);
        assertEquals(1000, result);

        // Test with null start object
        try {
            BaseSingleFieldPeriod.between(null, end, zeroInstance);
            fail("Expected IllegalArgumentException");
        } catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
            assertEquals("ReadablePartial objects must not be null", e.getMessage());
        }

        // Test with null end object
        try {
            BaseSingleFieldPeriod.between(start, null, zeroInstance);
            fail("Expected IllegalArgumentException");
        } catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
            assertEquals("ReadablePartial objects must not be null", e.getMessage());
        }

        // Test with different set of fields
        ReadablePartial start2 = new Period().withYears(1).withDays(1);
        ReadablePartial end2 = new Period().withYears(1).withMonths(1);
        try {
            BaseSingleFieldPeriod.between(start2, end2, zeroInstance);
            fail("Expected IllegalArgumentException");
        } catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
            assertEquals("ReadablePartial objects must have the same set of fields", e.getMessage());
        }

        // Test with non-contiguous objects
        long startMillis2 = PARIS.convertLocalToUTC(123456789000L);
        long endMillis2 = PARIS.convertLocalToUTC(startMillis2 + 900000);
        ReadablePartial start3 = new Period().withMillis(startMillis2);
        ReadablePartial end3 = new Period().withMillis(endMillis2);
        try {
            BaseSingleFieldPeriod.between(start3, end3, zeroInstance);
            fail("Expected IllegalArgumentException");
        } catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
            assertEquals("ReadablePartial objects must be contiguous", e.getMessage());
        }
    }
}
```
These unit tests cover most of the edge cases and exceptions that could be thrown by the `between` method, including null objects, objects with different fields, and non-contiguous objects.

public class TestDateTimeFormatter extends TestCase  {
    //...

    // Unit tests
    public void testParseLocalDate_simple() {
        assertEquals(new LocalDate(2004, 6, 9), g.parseLocalDate("2004-06-09T10:20:30Z"));
        assertEquals(new LocalDate(2004, 6, 9), g.parseLocalDate("2004-06-09T10:20:30+18:00"));
        assertEquals(new LocalDate(2004, 6, 9), g.parseLocalDate("2004-06-09T10:20:30-18:00"));
        assertEquals(new LocalDate(2004, 6, 9),
                g.withChronology(BUDDHIST_PARIS).parseLocalDate("2004-06-09T10:20:30Z"));
        try {
            g.parseDateTime("ABC");
            fail();
        } catch (IllegalArgumentException ex) {}
    }

    //...
}
```
In this example, I used the `assertEquals` method to validate that the expected `LocalDate` object matches the actual `LocalDate` object returned by the `parseLocalDate` method. Note that if the parser is unable to parse the input string, it should throw an `IllegalArgumentException`, which is caught and asserted as a `fail` in the test case.
